review.title: Streaming Algorithms for News and Scientific Literature Recommendation: Submodular Maximization with a d-Knapsack Constraint
review.abstract: Submodular maximization problems belong to the family of combinatorial optimization problems and enjoy wide applications. In this paper, we focus on the problem of maximizing a monotone submodular function subject to a $d$-knapsack constraint, for which we propose a streaming algorithm that achieves a $\left(\frac{1}{1+d}-\epsilon\right)$-approximation of the optimal value, while it only needs one single pass through the dataset without storing all the data in the memory. In our experiments, we extensively evaluate the effectiveness of our proposed algorithm via two applications: news recommendation and scientific literature recommendation. It is observed that the proposed streaming algorithm achieves both execution speedup and memory saving by several orders of magnitude, compared with existing approaches.

sections.heading: IV. APPLICATIONS
sections.text: In this section we discuss two real-life applications for Algorithm 4: Recommendation of news and recommendation of scientific literature.

sections.heading: A. News Recommendation
sections.text: A messaging recommendation system helps people quickly download the information they need. Specifically, it provides the most relevant and diversified messages to people by using their behavior as a submodular maximization problem. Based on the learning outcome, a classic greedy algorithm [4] has been implemented to provide a range of relevant articles to users. However, the large amount of data in the datasets prevents classical greedy algorithms from producing the solution in time due to their expensive computing costs. Additionally, it simplifies user reading behavior too much where it assumes that each user is reading a fixed number of articles per day.

sections.heading: B. Scientific Literature Recommendation
sections.text: Next, we present an application in the scientific literature that represents a scientific article. Researchers have to deal with an enormous amount of articles and gather information that interests them, where they have to filter the massive existing scientific literature and select the most useful ones. A common approach to finding the target literature is based on the so-called citation networks [24]. The authors in [24] map a citation network onto an evaluation matrix to filter research. sections.heading: V. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed a streaming algorithm to maximize a monotonous submodular function under a d-knapsack constraint. It leads to a (1 1 + 2d −) approximation of the optimal value and requires only a single pass through the dataset and a small memory size. It achieves a large fraction of the usefulness value achieved by the greedy algorithm at significantly lower computational costs, making it very practical to implement. Our algorithm offers a more efficient way to solve the associated combinatorial optimization problems that many good applications could find, such as in the recommendations for news and scientific literature shown in the paper.
